review_title: Great place to work and make lasting relationships!
job_title: Oil Rig Operator in Greeley, CO
pros:
Quiet, private/secluded workplace away from prying eyes.

I loved my job at Anadarko! The relationships I made there (and one in particular) changed my life forever, and truly set me on a completely different course than I ever anticipated.

I loved that most of what I did there was outside, and it gave me an excuse to get out and get some fresh air, even in the middle of the night. They gave me a company vehicle to drive, and it really came in handy when I needed to haul personal items with or for my family. I pretty much had free reign of the property, and there was enough room on site to store personal items, as well.

Even though some things came up in my personal life that led to my separation there, I don’t have anything but good memories of my time at Anadarko. I kind of regret the way I behaved my last day on the job, and I left some things behind that other people ended up having to clean up in my absence (literally and figuratively). It was kind of embarrassing, but it’s like no real big deal, I’m sure.

For now, I’m staying busy and still working with some petroleum products. One day, I’m sure that that last day there will just be an old memory, and I can probably go back to Anadarko (now Oxy), if I ever move back to Colorado from my current residence in Wisconsin. I will be sure to bring my updated resume and hope for the best. I can’t wait to be back there, even though I hear that they removed my favorite oil batteries.
cons: None, really, except that the narrow hatches on the oil batteries can make it a bit difficult to maneuver for some purposes.

review_title: Geologist II & Sr. Geologist with Anadarko Petroleum
pros: The people at Anadarko are its best asset.  I was glad to come to work with respected friends and colleagues everyday.  The compensation was good, but the PTO and Friday's off were excellent perks.
cons:
While technical training is something that Anadarko touts it is common for geologists and engineers to be pigeonholed into roles which allow for little to no technical application.  The team to which I was last assigned was comprised of a mixture of geologists and engineers.  The consensus between everyone on the team is that we all became worse geologists and engineers in that role.

Anadarko is probably one of the least innovative workplaces in the industry.  While they have an exploration group, the team isn't given nearly enough time to work quality prospects.  At the time that I left the company the exploration geologists were given 90 days to identify an opportunity and complete a full regional evaluation.  It is no wonder that the company hadn't made a significant onshore discovery in the last decade and they've relied on paying premium prices for acreage followed by copy-catting other innovative E&Ps.

The last thing is the core values.  Anadarko is so proud of their core values but it's just lip-service.  You are hammered with talk about the values but it's totally insincere and it's a way to ding people on their end of year reviews.  Get rid of that nonsense.

review_title: Industry Leading Benefits/Lack of vision beyond next quarterly statement
pros:
Combine PTO with 9/80 schedule and paid holidays and you work less days than a school teacher. Great bonus program and benefits package. Peer leading maternity/paternity leave. If you have the unfortunate luck of being marooned in Midland you are paid a 25% “geographic premium” which means a big fat paycheck, and the bar for Midland employees’ work product is pretty low. A culture that fosters physical fitness, I.e. beautiful fitness centers (at The Woodlands campus) and long lunches. Cafes are exquisite and prices for food are low in The Woodlands campus. The community around The Woodlands office is amazingly beautiful, well thought-out, and cheap! Most managers are accommodating to flexible and unique work schedules. 

Bottom line, if you are willing to put up with a crappy culture and lucky enough to be in working in The Woodlands office it’s like getting paid to do almost nothing and living/working in Disney World.
cons: Management at all levels are inept, which is shocking given the size of the company. Corporate culture went in the crapper in the downturn and never recovered. Midland office debacle. Denver office in peril of closing.

review_title: Great field staff, poor middle management
pros: Compensation and benefits, down-to-earth field employees, upper management that is trying to get the company through the difficulties of growth.
cons: Disconnect between the field and upper management due to middle level managers, middle level managers do not appreciate the field, safety sacrificed for production, attitude from middle level managers of "good riddance" towards employees that are leaving rather than making the effort to keep employees, low morale for field employees and low trust environment with management, thorough career guides developed but not followed (employees with years of experience, education, and certifications kept at entry-level positions), good-ole-boy club, too many "yes men."

review_title: Amazing when I started, not so now
pros: Anadarko has some amazing benefits. You are offered a significant amount of PTO based on your age, and a lot of on site perks. And of course the 9/80 schedule is amazing.
cons: They changed the bonus structure which significantly decreased. Very political. It's all about who you know. A lot of good people where laid off. I know a girl who received Needs improvement on her review and is still there while some one who received exceeds expectations was let go. The amount of management positions is absolutely ridiculous, and majority of time they are not even competent to have the position. And whatever you do, do not go to HR. They are not on your side!

pros: Potential to be employed by a well-established, successful public oil and gas company that provides a well rounded benefits and comp package.
cons: The decision to move the Delaware Basin asset team to Midland from The Woodlands has resulted in 55-60%  attrition, to date, in the Land department as well as considerable turnover in other disciplines as well. This attrition has resulted in a serious culture catastrophe. Employees no longer trust middle and upper management due to the disastrous outcome of the decision to move people out to Midland without consideration of the cost of living in Midland and general decrease of quality of life in the area, coupled with the lack of succession-planning once most of the teams inevitably  left the company after their retention bonus term expired. As a Land professional, I would discourage others from joining Anadarko in Midland. There has been absolutely no benefit of moving the asset team “closer to the action” to Midland due to the handcuffs and red tape internal policies on doing deals and developing new business that Land professionals face internally with the Company.

pros: Freedom to innovate and explore; kind coworkers; flexible schedule; great benefits; plenty of vacation.

review_title: You'd be hard-pressed to find another company as fantastic

2 annual bonus plans: individual and company performance based

pros: The PTO and pay are comperable in the industry, and the 9/80 schedule allows for long weekends- which is nice for people that want that work/life balance

There is big money being lost by the company due to the time it takes to make changes.

job_title: IT Systems Analyst in The Woodlands, TX

review_title: Grew too fast without checks and balances

cons: Good old boy system dominates culture, no matter what HR says.  Many in management, from supervisors up to VPs, should not be in management.  The growth APC underwent promoted many who should never have been promoted in the beginning.  Period.  HR did not override favoritism which dominates during times of layoffs.

pros: Access to all levels of management due to the open door policy, opportunities to make meaninful contributions by performing value-added duties, strong emphasis on developing presentation skills and interacting with upper management, core values are central to all aspects of the company and are highly enforced, incredible amenities and work-life balance (9/80 schedule, on-site cafeterias and fitness centers).
cons: Long internship (13 weeks) and rigorous work schedule can force you to change your summer plans to be able to complete the internship.  The business is obviously sensitive to commodity prices, so interning during a down period reveals some discouraged outlooks among the full-time employees.

job_title: Senior Staff Analyst in Houston, TX

cons: I really have nothing negative to say about the place. I have done work with Anadarko for several years prior to taking a position here and I truly enjoy the work and the people. I think the only potential con is the small size of the company leads to lots of direct interaction with senior management. I personally like this as you know what is going on but others would prefer to be more anonymous.

pros: Anadarko invests heavily in their employees, providing many opportunities to grow and develop as a professional.  This includes setting annual goals for yourself and offering classes for development.  What I enjoy the most about Anadarko is how involved they are with the community.  They truly care about people, the community and the environment.  I have never worked for a company that has invested so much time and effort in fundraising and volunteering events.  It is about being a difference maker and leaving a positive impact on others.

job_title: Accountant II in The Woodlands, TX

Political infighting and conflicting objectives seems to be pervasive in many middle management tiers leading to an overall unfocused environment.

With the price of oil down though hopefully APC as well as other O&G companies can learn to value what scm can actually do for the industry as out of the box thinking and innovation for cost management and operational efficiency are critical in survival.

review_title: Love them when they loved me back

Overall the culture suffered a bit when the prices of oil fell and layoffs happened, but it is recovering and management is doing an awesome job at pulling everyone together by focusing on core values. Parking/RTD passes are paid for. Gym subsidies. Competitive salaries... the list goes on and the benefits seem endless. Overall a fantastic company to work for!!!
cons: The turnover that the low oil prices has created has put a bit of strain on the people who still remain workload-wise. Nothing unmanageable.

review_title: Great Company - Some departments could use improvement
pros: Anadarko has wonderful employees that are willing to help each other to get the job done quickly and effectively. We have great bonuses, benefits, PTO and tons of wonderful volunteer opportunities. Our 9/80 schedule allows for more free time which helps balance work and home life. Though the job can be demanding and stressful at times, I find that the time I spend with my coworkers and the results we achieve as a team make the stressful times worth it.
cons: Some department managers are stuck in the boys’ club mentality. If you are from the younger generation and are a woman, working in one of these departments means you have to prove yourself more. Having a tough skin will be necessary and you will need to advocate for yourself much more than you would in other departments. I want to stress that not all departments are like this. The US Onshore business has been a mess the past few years with the pinnacle of mismanagement being the horribly executed Midland relocation and the toll it has taken on the Delaware Basin team. 

Some of the 2017 highlights include: Since the Midland announcement in Sept 2016 there has been 100% turnover at the individual contributor level on the West Texas drilling & completions team, ALL of the drilling leadership has left (supervisors, managers, GMs, and the VP retired), 3-4 asset team reorgs have been fumbled through (maybe 5, hard to keep up), a safety stand down luncheon was held that was led by APC’s CAO (an attorney runs the HSE team of course) where office based employees gave advice on how to improve the disastrous safety record, a new line of VP leadership was introduced so the VP could report to a VP, the EVP who led the charge to Midland left the company, and now multiple managers in the Midland office are being relocated back to Houston less than 8 months after moving here with their families. It has been a nightmarish joke.

It really is shocking given what the organization looked like 5 years ago. As it stands now, the majority of the Delaware Basin team hasn’t worked Delaware Basin for much more than a year. The threats and coercion the leadership team utilized to get employees to relocate was a disgrace and they’re dealing with the consequences of that as employees in key disciplines continue to leave. Just to be clear, employees were told they would be fired for cause without severance if they were offered a position in Midland and turned it down.

If you are a young/mid-career engineer or geoscientist and are fortunate enough to have options, avoid this place like the plague.
